title: Covid-19 Outbreaks Disrupt Princeton, Cornell End of Term
summary: Several colleges and universities shut down in-person final exams and nonacademic events as the Omicron variant drives a surge in infections. A sharp rise in Covid-19 cases on several campuses is prompting some colleges and universities to reinstate remote learning and require booster vaccination shots, upending the last days of the fall term and casting doubt over whether schools will remain in-person heading into next year.

title: SEC Floats Money-Fund, Stock Rules
summary: Wall Street regulators moved forward on four plans, advancing far-reaching agenda under Chairman Gary Gensler. WASHINGTON-The Securities and Exchange Commission issued a raft of proposals Wednesday including measures aimed at shoring up money-market funds and curbing executives' ability to trade their own companies' stock.

title: Hawkish Fed Talk, Dovish Action
summary: The central bank signals negative real interest rates throughout 2022.. The Federal Reserve has retired the word "transitory" and now admits that inflation is high, but it isn't in any rush to do much about it. That was the message Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) and Chairman Jerome Powell, whose actions said inflation really is transitory, even if it's now impolitic for them to say so.

title: The Xi-Putin Entente Rises
summary: Both share a goal of undermining the U.S.-led global order.. The gushing remarks at Wednesday's video meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping have drawn renewed attention to an underplayed story: The tightening strategic embrace between America's two most formidable geopolitical competitors. Moscow and Beijing have held each other at arm's length for decades, but as the world becomes less stable, both see regional advantages from rolling back American power and prosperity.

title: Biden Raises the Ethanol Gas Tax
summary: Higher renewable fuel mandates may put refiners out of business.. President Biden last week celebrated a small decline in gasoline prices. Meantime, his Environmental Protection Agency proposed changes to the renewable fuel standard-aka the ethanol mandate-that will raise them.

title: The Chinese Economy's Tough Transition
summary: Slowing growth isn't helping Xi Jinping's political designs.. No one said China's economic pivot from real estate would be easy, and now along come more data to prove the point. It's clearer by the day that China's economy is under growing pressure, which means so is President Xi Jinping.

title: A Hostile Takeover of the FDIC
summary: Board members had always respected the agency's independence-until now.. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is led by a five-member board, which for decades has delegated day-to-day operations to its chairman, who by statute serves a five-year term. This structure was designed to ensure independence from changing political administrations and has led to a long legacy of collegiality. For 88 years the chairman has controlled the board agenda and worked collaboratively with other board members.

title: Jen Psaki Tries to 'Fake' Out the CBO's Build Back Better Score
summary: She says it didn't evaluate the 'actual bill,' but the legislation is meant to deceive.. Desperate to pass yet another gargantuan spending bill, President Biden has declared war on a federal agency Vice President Biden regularly praised-the Congressional Budget Office.

title: John Kerry's Financial Crusade Against Oil and Gas
summary: Public officials have told the climate envoy to stop trying to raise energy costs for U.S. consumers.. 'The reality is the Biden administration is not standing in the way of increasing domestic oil production to meet today's energy needs," Deputy Energy Secretary David Turk asserted at the World Petroleum Congress in Houston last week. Really? He might want to check with John Kerry.

title: Vol. 34, No. 11: Political Doctors
summary: Most Popular News. When celebrity surgeon Mehmet Oz, known as Dr. Oz, filed papers to run for a Senate seat in Pennsylvania, it also triggered a trip to our stylebook for Journal editors.

title: The Midwest's Tornadoes Predate Global Warming
summary: Activists who insist on a relationship between climate change and twisters can't explain the deadly storms of yesteryear.. Activists wasted no time attributing last week's tragic tornado outbreak in the Midwest to climate change. My hometown in southwest Indiana would like a word.

title: Hackers Backed by China Seen Exploiting Security Flaw in Internet Software
summary: Researchers call it one of the most dire cybersecurity threats to emerge in years and could enable devastating attacks. Hackers linked to China and other governments are among a growing assortment of cyberattackers seeking to exploit a widespread and severe vulnerability in computer server software, according to cybersecurity firms and Microsoft Corp.

title: An Obituary Is the Story of a Life, Not a Death
summary: That's what I learned from writing the 'In Memoriam' column.. I didn't set out to write obituaries. I suppose no one does. A couple of years ago, I began editing the quarterly magazine of an academic honor society. One of my duties involved writing death notices of deceased members.

title: Blame Voters for the Rising Crime Rate
summary: Just maybe, voters are starting to regret the consequences of electing progressives.. For the stressed-out voters in your political life, an aphorism to print and wrap in ribbon for Christmas giving is "Live and learn." Though in these crime-sodden times, it might need revision: "Die and learn."

title: Container Imports Tumble at Los Angeles, Long Beach Ports
summary: Last month's surprise decline in inbound volumes seemed to reflect an increased number of smaller ships arriving at the ports, even as the line for entry to the major U.S. gateway complex grows. Container imports at the largest U.S. gateway for seaborne goods trade fell sharply in November, even as backups of ships waiting to unload cargo at the Southern California ports have been growing.

title: Apple Delays Return to Office, Closes Three Stores as Covid Cases Rise
summary: The iPhone maker has delayed its return-to-office plan several times. Apple Inc. has once again delayed its plans to return to the office as concerns mount about the Omicron variant of the virus that causes Covid-19, and the company also closed three retail locations after a rise in cases at those stores.

title: 'Tinderbox' Review: Remaking a Medium
summary: On its 50th anniversary, an oral history of HBO, from creative brainstorms and fearless innovation to executive tantrums, backstabbing and worse.. Nestled in my bookshelves is an early edition of "An Encyclopedia of World History," Harvard professor William Langer's dense tome covering ancient, medieval and modern times in 1,243 pages. Now it's challenged for heft by James Andrew Miller's latest book, which takes only a couple of hundred fewer pages to recount the five-decade oral history of . . . Home Box Office!

title: Senate Passes $778 Billion Defense-Policy Bill
summary: NDAA package establishes commission to investigate Afghanistan war, makes changes to military-justice system. WASHINGTON-The Senate on Wednesday voted 88-11 to pass a $778 billion defense-policy bill that will establish a commission to investigate America's longest war, and make historic changes to the military-justice system.

title: Democrats' $2 Trillion Package Stalls as Manchin Talks Bog Down
summary: Enhanced child tax credit in danger of lapsing after final payments issued Wednesday. WASHINGTON-Democrats braced for weeks of delay and uncertainty on their roughly $2 trillion education, healthcare and climate package they had hoped to finish by year end, as efforts faltered to secure the pivotal support of Sen. Joe Manchin (D., W.Va.) for the bill.

title: Transcript: Fed Chief Powell's Postmeeting Press Conference
summary: Resume Subscription. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell discussed the central bank's decision not to raise interest rates and its move to more quickly reduce the pace of its asset purchases, during a press conference after the Fed's monetary policy meeting Wednesday. He also talked about the Fed's expectations for a strengthening labor market and its outlook for inflation, which it expects to end this year well above its 2% target before easing somewhat by the end of 2022. Here is a transcript, lightly edited for clarity and length.

title: Fed Officials Project Three Rate Rises Next Year and Accelerate Wind-Down of Stimulus
summary: Reducing bond-buying program more quickly opens door to earlier interest rate rise. The Federal Reserve set the stage for a series of interest rate increases beginning next spring, completing a major policy pivot that showed much greater concern about the potential for inflation to stay high.

title: Stocks Rally as Investors Welcome Fed Decision
summary: S&P 500, Nasdaq, Dow industrials all advance more than 1%; oil prices rise. U.S. stocks rose after Federal Reserve officials approved plans to more quickly wind down pandemic stimulus efforts, giving investors more insight into the central bank's response to high inflation.

title: Airline CEOs Face Senators' Queries About Bumpy Travel Recovery
summary: Executives were asked about flight disruptions, refund policies, pilot hiring after receiving billions in federal aid. Airline executives answered lawmakers' questions about the travel recovery in a wide-ranging hearing Wednesday called to evaluate the success of billions of dollars in government aid.

title: Biden Promises Funding for Cleanup After Kentucky Tornadoes
summary: Resume Subscription. President Biden said Wednesday the federal government will cover 100% of the costs associated with emergency disaster response for the first 30 days after this weekend's tornadoes, including shelter and debris removal, as he visited parts of Kentucky where clean up continues.

title: Alvin Ailey Springs Back Into Live Performance
summary: The Troupe's current run at City Center includes two live premieres and four newly staged productions.. New York

title: 'Revealing Krishna: Journey to Cambodia's Sacred Mountain' Review: Pivoting Our View of a Sculpture
summary: Research and collaboration have reconfigured a work from around the year 600, transforming its presence.. Cleveland

title: Biden to Nominate Caroline Kennedy as Ambassador to Australia
summary: The president is also nominating Olympic figure skating medalist Michelle Kwan as ambassador to Belize. WASHINGTON-President Biden will nominate Caroline Kennedy to be U.S. ambassador to Australia, the White House said Wednesday.

title: Cuomo, Krugman and Kentucky
summary: New York Times columnist exploits tragedy to recycle dubious claim.. "On a single Kentucky street, the tornado killed 7 children," reads the headline on an Associated Press story today. The AP's Claire Galofaro and John Raby report from Bowling Green:

title: Navy Grapples With Jet Fuel Leak in Hawaii That Sickened Residents
summary: Pentagon's No. 2 toured Red Hill storage facility Tuesday; residents have complained of contaminated drinking water. HONOLULU-The leak of jet fuel from a World War II-era storage facility into a local aquifer has displaced more than 3,000 military service members and their families, sickened residents and put renewed pressure on the military to invest millions to stop future leaks.

title: Looking for an Electric Pickup Truck? More Options Are on the Way
summary: GM teases electric version of its GMC Sierra; Toyota reveals plans for future electric truck. The U.S. auto industry's truck wars are going electric.

title: Omicron Drives Record Daily Covid-19 Case Count in U.K.
summary: The variant's growth in the U.K. suggests it can outcompete the Delta variant, currently dominant in the U.S. and much of Europe. LONDON-The U.K. reported its highest daily number of cases of Covid-19 on Wednesday, as a senior British health official warned the fast-spreading Omicron variant posed the most significant threat since the start of the pandemic.

title: Police Officers Can Be Held Liable for Death of Tony Timpa, Court Rules
summary: Dallas case is first major test of lawfulness of prone restraint since Derek Chauvin's murder conviction. A federal appeals court on Wednesday ruled that four Dallas police officers can be held liable in the 2016 death of Tony Timpa, a mentally ill Dallas man who died after police knelt on his back and shoulders for more than 14 minutes in an encounter captured on body-camera footage.

title: Treasury Yields Rise After Fed Signals Turn to Tighter Monetary Policy
summary: Officials also plan to accelerate wind-down of bond purchases as they look to slow inflation. U.S. government bond yields edged higher Wednesday after the Federal Reserve confirmed investors' expectations that it was poised to make a sharp turn to tighter monetary policy.

title: Putin, Xi Affirm Cooperative Effort to Counter Western Pressure
summary: Leaders agreed to work together to defend their nations' security interests amid high tensions with U.S., Europe. MOSCOW-Russian President Vladimir Putin and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, agreed to rebuff Western intrusion into their countries' internal affairs and boost efforts to defend their nations' security interests, strengthening cooperation between Moscow and Beijing as both face pressure from the U.S. and Europe.

title: Mark Meadows and Contempt of Congress: What to Know
summary: Former Trump chief of staff faces possible prosecution for defying subpoena from committee investigating Jan. 6 attack on Capitol. The House of Representatives voted late Tuesday to hold Mark Meadows, former President Donald Trump's last chief of staff, in contempt of Congress for refusing to comply with a subpoena requiring his testimony on his activities and communications surrounding the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol. Here is some context for that development.

title: Wax On, Wax Off (Thursday Crossword, December 16)
U.S. Healthcare Spending Rose Nearly 10% in 2020, Report Finds
summary: The increase was driven largely by a massive influx of federal dollars to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. WASHINGTON-U.S. healthcare spending surged nearly 10% last year to more than $4 trillion as the federal government poured billions of dollars into assisting hospitals, states and medical providers with the pandemic, according to a new government report, setting a galloping pace compared with 2019 when the U.S. saw a 4.3% jump.

title: The Outlook for Inflation-Near Term and Far
summary: Economist Nela Richardson says inflation will settle down, but won't be as low as it was before the pandemic for a while. U.S. inflation hit a 39-year high in November, with prices up 6.8% from a year before, as measured by the Labor Department's consumer-price index. The Wall Street Journal sat down with Nela Richardson, chief economist at human-resources software firm Automatic Data Processing Inc., to learn what high inflation means for consumers, and what to expect in 2022.

title: Harvard Professor Charles Lieber's Trial Gets Under Way
summary: Nanoscientist's lawyer says he was careless, not criminal, in failing to report some ties to Chinese university. BOSTON-Prosecutors and defense lawyers delivered opening statements in the closely watched trial of Harvard chemistry professor Charles Lieber in Massachusetts federal court on Wednesday, with Mr. Lieber's defense team portraying the scientist's conduct as careless but not criminal.

title: There Are Scarier Things Than a Hawkish Fed
summary: The Federal Reserve could make a mistake by tightening too aggressively, but even worse would be a Covid-19 outbreak that takes tightening off the table. The Federal Reserve might be on its way to making a mistake, but it is hard to know in which direction.

title: Black Feminist bell hooks Dies at 69
summary: Scholar wrote about intersection of feminism, politics, race, gender and culture. Black feminist scholar, author and poet bell hooks, who wrote about the intersection of feminism, politics, race, gender and culture, died on Wednesday. She was 69.

title: Superfast NASA Spacecraft Kisses the Sun for First Time Ever
summary: The Parker Solar Probe plunged into the sun's atmosphere and came within 8.1 million miles of the surface. A car-size spacecraft described as the fastest human-made object zoomed inside the sun's atmosphere for the first time ever last spring and gathered scientific data that could help unlock the secrets of our host star, scientists involved with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration mission said Tuesday.

title: Derek Chauvin Pleads Guilty to Violating George Floyd's Civil Rights
summary: Plea deal with prosecutors means government will seek a 300-month maximum sentence instead of life. MINNEAPOLIS-Derek Chauvin pleaded guilty to federal civil-rights charges stemming from the May 2020 murder of George Floyd and a separate case involving a 14-year-old boy, reversing an earlier not-guilty plea Wednesday after striking an agreement with prosecutors.

title: What to Watch: Seven Movies and Series to Stream This Week
summary: Resume Subscription. "Yellowstone" gets a prequel ("1883"); Will Forte's MacGruber gets a series ("MacGruber"); and Sam Elliott shows up in both. Plus, Gloria Calderón Kellett weaves together a story about family, the holidays and sex in "With Love." Here's where to stream it all:

title: Craving a Ski Trip in the Rockies? The Top Spots Are All Spruced Up This Winter
summary: Luxurious new hotels, major renovations, heated chairlifts, elevating dining-the best ski areas in the Rocky Mountains are even better this year. Here, a look at some of the most notable changes afoot.. WHILE MANY of us were in deep hibernation mode last winter, the ski crowd wasn't so easily deterred. According to the National Ski Area Association, operators in the Rocky Mountains reported their second busiest season in four decades. Since then, the most popular mountain resorts, intent on keeping those snow bums content, have been rolling out a raft of improvements and innovations-brand new hotels, spiffily remade ones, heated chairlifts, roving raclette carts and whiskey tastings are all on tap. Here, a few of the latest offerings.

title: Surging Fertilizer Costs Push Farms to Shift Planting Plans, Raise Prices
summary: Higher prices for commodities like corn would further inflate prices cereal, cooking oil, beef and other meat. Fertilizer prices have more than doubled over the past year, frustrating U.S. farmers, who now are adjusting spring planting plans and warning about the potential for higher food prices.

title: NFL and NBA Games Are Now Being Decided by Covid Tests
summary: NFL teams like the Browns and Rams are suffering through outbreaks while NBA stars such as Giannis Antetokounmpo and James Harden are sidelined by the virus in a paradigm that accepts competitive imbalances.. The Cleveland Browns' game on Saturday night against the Las Vegas Raiders is a critical matchup with enormous playoff implications and one clear problem: The Browns are in the middle of Covid-19 outbreak that has gutted their roster.

title: Companies Could Get Extended Accounting Relief for Libor Changeover
summary: The Financial Accounting Standards Board voted to propose offering the assistance through 2024. U.S. companies could get a longer stretch of accounting relief for their transition away from the London interbank offered rate under a new proposal from the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: U.S. Set to Ban American Investment in Some Chinese Companies
summary: A draft Treasury Department announcement says the companies, including a large drone maker, help China's mass surveillance of Muslim ethnic groups. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration plans to ban American investment in the world's largest drone-maker and seven other Chinese companies for what the U.S. says are their roles in China's mass surveillance of Muslim ethnic groups.

title: GM, Ford CFOs Bring Different Backgrounds to Similar Challenges
summary: Just over a year into their roles, the two CFOs are allocating billions of dollars to overhaul their businesses amid change in the industry. General Motors Co. and Ford Motor Co. face many of the same challenges, including chip shortages and supply-chain disruptions. The auto makers, however, hired finance chiefs with vastly different backgrounds to help them navigate what is poised to be a transformative period for the automotive industry.

title: CDC's Early Covid-19 Test Hampered by Design Flaw, Contamination
summary: Agency investigation adds to understanding of missteps in early response to the pandemic. A design flaw and contamination caused the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's initial batch of Covid-19 tests to fail, an investigation by the agency concluded, adding to the understanding of a major misstep in the early U.S. response to the pandemic.

title: The Treasury Has a Bond Bargain for You
summary: I bonds, currently paying 7.12%, are a great hedge against inflation.. The end of the year is an excellent time to re-evaluate your investment portfolio-especially this year. If you started 2020 with the often recommended ratio of three quarters of your assets in common stocks and one quarter in safe bonds, that's not the ratio you actually have now. Stocks enjoyed returns of about 25% this year, while indexed bond portfolios declined. Your stock allocation will likely be more than four times what you have in bonds.

title: Smash and Grab? Don't Come to Arizona
summary: Unlike soft-on-crime California, we take retail theft seriously.. Phoenix

title: Covid-19 Cuts Short Blinken's Effort to Rally Asian States Against China
summary: The Secretary of State dropped planned meetings in Thailand after a journalist tested positive. Secretary of State Antony Blinken ended a diplomatic tour of Southeast Asia on Wednesday after at least one person traveling with him tested positive for the coronavirus, cutting short an effort to rally friendly Asian nations to join Washington in confronting an assertive China.

title: Amtrak's New $22 Billion Man
summary: Stephen Gardner will be the railroad's fifth chief executive since 2016. Amtrak named Stephen Gardner its new chief executive on Wednesday, tapping a longtime executive to manage the biggest infusion of federal funding in the railroad's half-century history.

title: Anchorage Capital Is Closing $7.4 Billion Flagship Hedge Fund
summary: Letter to investors reports closing of Anchorage Capital Partners and eventual return of money to clients. Anchorage Capital Group, one of the biggest hedge-fund investors in distressed debt, is closing its flagship fund after 18 years and returning the $7.4 billion it manages to clients, citing a market environment in which cheap money has helped keep stock and bond prices elevated while suppressing corporate defaults.

title: Child Tax Credit Payments 2021: Who Is Eligible and How Much Are They?
summary: Tax credit is a federal benefit that reduces income tax liability for people with children. The sixth monthly payments of the child tax credit hit Americans' bank accounts Dec. 15, continuing an experiment in family and fiscal policy that is now in limbo as Congress decides what to do about the program going forward. Democrats tout the monthly payments as a way to reduce child poverty and change annual lump-sum tax refunds into a more reliable stream of income. Republicans have criticized the changes for breaking the prior link between the credit and earned income.

title: Debating Vaccine Mandates for Healthcare Workers
summary: The Biden administration's mandate has already had real consequences at my clinic.. Regarding your editorial "Biden's Vaccine Mandate Wipeout" (Dec. 10): I want my healthcare providers to be vaccinated for two reasons. First, we in the medical profession have an obligation not to spread disease to our patients, and because of our exposure to sick people, we have a much higher risk of acquiring infection and infecting others.

title: MIT Responds on Research Collaboration With China
summary: Cutting off all work with China would hamper progress in the U.S.. Michelle Bethel is right that U.S. research relationships with institutions in China require serious care and consideration ("Is MIT's Research Helping the Chinese Military?" op-ed, Dec. 11). But her assertions about the McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT are misplaced.

title: China Is a Tougher Foe Than the Soviet Union
summary: The architects of U.S. policy must demonstrate strategic and practical flexibility, not ideological brain freeze.. Regarding Hal Brands's "Containment Can Work Against China, Too" (Review, Dec. 4): The clear benefit of containment of the Soviet Union was a path to global stability, economic growth, trade and civil liberties. There were missteps, but the policy won the Cold War without nuclear destruction.

title: Older Workers Can Keep Up
summary: Most are eager to learn technologies to enhance productivity.. Most older workers are eager to learn technologies to enhance productivity ("Older Workers and Tech," Journal Report, Nov. 29). In October alone, Older Adults Technology Services hosted 23,000 visitors to our online-learning programs, where they brushed up on tech skills. A woman in Colorado recently told me that "learning these new skills saved my job."

title: How We Think About Mental Illness
summary: Has there truly been an exponential rise in its incidence?. In 1952 the American Psychiatric Association published the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, citing 60 distinct disorders ("The Paradox of Resilience," Bookshelf, Dec. 6). The newer editions of the DSM list over 300 distinct, diagnosable mental disorders.

title: Bob Dole Was Pro-Term Limits
summary: Taking advantage of a seniority system in Congress today is not mutually exclusive with building a better Congress for tomorrow.. A letter (Dec. 9) cites Bob Dole's contributions as a reason America shouldn't adopt term limits. There's one problem: Dole himself supported term limits. He ran for president on a pro-term-limits platform and voted for term-limits constitutional amendments in the Senate. He understood that taking advantage of a seniority system in Congress today is not mutually exclusive with building a better Congress for tomorrow.

title: Bugatti? Check. Patek Philippe? Check. North Fork Vineyard? Check.
summary: Resume Subscription. Randy Frankel sported white patched jeans and a snug T-shirt that telegraphed his current passions-Weekends, Wine and Dogs-as he cradled a 4-pound Yorkie and surveyed his latest acquisition, Ruland Farm. He purchased the 66-acre property on Long Island's North Fork in July 2021 for just under $3.2 million. Now he is transforming it to a vineyard, while restoring its 2,500-square-foot home for the use of his daughters. The home, originally 1,200 square feet, was built in 1716, according to Mr. Frankel.

title: Biometrics Company Clear Brings Its Scanners to Retail Stores
summary: The holiday-season installations are aimed at reaching customers beyond the airport. Clear Secure Inc., an identification services company known for its expedited screening product for air travelers, is bringing its biometric sign-up scanners to locations beyond airports.

title: Omicron Variant Symptoms and Covid-19 Vaccines: What to Know
summary: New variant raises concerns but might still remain vulnerable to current vaccines. Omicron is the latest variant of the coronavirus to raise concerns about the course of the pandemic in the U.S. and world-wide. In mid-December, the Omicron variant accounted for an estimated 3% of Covid-19 cases in the U.S. and more than one in eight cases in the New York and New Jersey area, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. As Omicron gains ground, here's what we know so far about the variant first detected in southern Africa.

title: SEC Proposes Tighter Rules on Insider Trading, Stock Buybacks
summary: Executives would have to wait 120 days before buying or selling their company's stock. WASHINGTON-Wall Street's regulator is putting forward tighter rules on how and when corporate insiders can sell their companies' stocks, just as executives are cashing in at historic levels.

title: The Best Architecture of 2021: Constraints That Set Creativity Free
summary: Penn Station's Moynihan Train Hall, Smith College's Neilson Library, the renovated Denver Art Museum and other projects found success in tricky settings.. It is easy to assume that an artist is most creative when most free of constraints, but it is the other way around. The more constraints, the higher the order of thought needed to overcome them. Michelangelo found his David in a block of marble worked on by two other sculptors and then abandoned, and that was too shallow for such a heroic figure. Constraints do not guarantee success, of course, nor does their absence rule it out. Studio Gang's superbly tapered St. Regis Chicago, the year's most thrilling skyscraper, rose above a fairly open site facing Lake Michigan. But it is significant that many of this year's best buildings faced that most onerous of challenges, inserting an entirely new program behind a beloved historic facade.

title: Amazon Web Services Suffers Brief Outage
summary: AWS issues arise again after hourslong outage last week disrupted service across internet. Amazon.com Inc . 's cloud-computing unit suffered a brief outage Wednesday, stoking fears of a repeat of the hourslong outage last week that caused much of the internet to stop working.

title: Holiday Cheer Came too Early for Retailers
summary: Weaker-than-expected retail sales in November could reflect a pulling forward of some holiday shopping demand. Did Christmas come too early for retailers this year?

title: Russian Given Life Sentence for Killing of Chechen Rebel in Berlin
summary: Conviction of Vadim Krasikov adds to mounting tensions between Russia and West. BERLIN-A German court on Wednesday sentenced a Russian man to life in prison for shooting dead a former Chechen rebel leader in Berlin at the behest of Moscow, in a case that has further frayed already tense relations between Germany and Russia.

title: Iran Agrees to Allow Cameras Back at Karaj Centrifuge Production Site
summary: Tehran says IAEA can resume monitoring, averting clash with U.S. as talks to revive nuclear deal drag on. Iran has agreed to let the United Nations atomic agency monitor its production of critical centrifuge parts, ending a three-month deadlock and averting a fresh diplomatic clash with the U.S.

title: In Hollywood, Covid-19 Vaccines Create New Drama, Costs on Set
summary: Sean Penn says he won't work with unvaccinated crew members; TV actors without jabs are seeing their characters sidelined. LOS ANGELES-In Hollywood, soap opera characters portrayed by vaccine skeptics are being killed off or shipped away, set crews for Walt Disney Co. 's "Black Panther" sequel and other projects are being reprimanded or reassigned, and some A-list stars won't work with colleagues who haven't gotten a jab.

title: A Kitchen Infused With Personality
summary: Resume Subscription. For 20 years, Britt Whitfield had been a serial renovator-buy a house, fix it up, live in it for a couple of years, find the next fixer-upper start again-until the day her wife, Jacqui Scott, put her foot down and refused to move with their two young children again.

title: Retail Sales Rose 0.3% in November
summary: November spending outpacing price gains from year earlier, but cooled from October. Retail sales rose modestly at the start of the holiday season, as shoppers faced rising inflation and supply shortages, and some snapped up gifts earlier.

title: How 'Succession' Stoked a Frenzy for Status Baseball Caps
summary: To subtly telegraph their affluence, wealthy characters like Kendall Roy sport pricey cashmere caps. And somewhat improbably, these hats are selling out in real life, too.. AT FIRST GLANCE, the baseball caps worn by monied characters on series like "Succession" and "The Morning Show" appear entirely ordinary. They're black or navy. Most lack any frontal logo. If your TV is sufficiently high-def, however, you might see that they have a slightly flecked cashmere texture.

title: Eva Longoria Is Coming to CNN+ With Original Series 'Searching for Mexico'
summary: Actress, director and producer will be featured in a CNN+ show that explores Mexican cuisine. CNN said actress Eva Longoria is coming to its new streaming service with an original series that will follow her as she travels through Mexico and explores its cuisines.

title: Xi Jinping's Leadership Style: Micromanagement That Leaves Underlings Scrambling
summary: Resume Subscription. Earlier this year, Xi Jinping issued brief instructions to education officials in Beijing. China's leader wanted to reform the country's $100 billion private tutoring industry, which the state worried was helping well-to-do families gain advantages for their offspring and creating anxiety among families that couldn't afford the help.

title: Energy Crisis in Europe Intensifies
summary: Cold weather and fear of a Russian invasion of Ukraine send natural-gas prices into overdrive. LONDON-Winter has arrived for energy markets in Europe as fears of disruption from the military buildup on Russia's border with Ukraine and falling temperatures catapult prices higher.

title: Sotheby's Sells $7.3 Billion in Art, Fueled by Moneyed Millennials
summary: Auction house says millennials drove art market rebound by bidding up everything from luxury goods to NFTs. One of the world's chief auction houses has put the pandemic behind it, thanks mainly to millennials who splurged on everything from designer watches to digital artworks.

title: What Was News: 2021's Biggest Stories
summary: A timeline of the year, told through The Wall Street Journal's coverage.

title: Coal Company CEO Thrived After a Slow Start
summary: Michael K. Reilly, who has died at age 88, led a timely management buyout and escaped Enron's orbit. Michael K. Reilly's career looked unpromising. A so-so student, he suffered through two semesters at a business college only because his father insisted, then struggled to support his own family on jobs selling real estate and frozen steaks.

title: Top Public and Private Colleges in the West
summary: The region's top four public schools are in the University of California system in the WSJ/THE College Rankings. The University of California system has the top four public schools in the West and six of the top seven, in the Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education College Rankings. Stanford University is the region's top private school, followed by the California Institute of Technology.

title: JPMorgan's Big Healthcare Conference Goes Virtual
summary: The move comes after several biotechnology companies pulled out of planned in-person appearances at San Francisco event. JPMorgan Chase & Co. is moving its big annual healthcare conference in San Francisco to a virtual setting, telling participants the spreading Omicron variant of Covid-19 had made the in-person gathering too risky.

title: Trump Loses Bid to Shield Tax Returns From Congress
summary: Federal judge in D.C. dismissed the former president's lawsuit; Trump's lawyers file a notice of appeal. WASHINGTON-Former President Donald Trump lost his bid to shield his tax returns from the House Ways and Means Committee on Tuesday, after a federal judge dismissed the case.

title: China Presses EU Over Taiwan by Targeting One of Smallest Members
summary: Lithuania pulls diplomats from China, citing pressure from Beijing. Lithuania is pulling its diplomats out of China, after Beijing blocked its companies' access to its market in retaliation for the country's outreach to Taiwan.

title: Covid Is Disrupting Sports. Again.
summary: With cases rising and teams sidelined, recent days have been a blunt reminder that the virus remains a problem for leagues like the NFL, NBA and NHL.. The richest professional sports leagues in the world spent enormous sums of money and took extraordinary measures to play through the pandemic in 2020. They bubbled, tested, and traced their way to make it to 2021, when there was more optimism about a return to something that resembled normalcy.

title: Roblox, BlackBerry, Pfizer, Adagio Therapeutics: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Tests suggested that Pfizer's Covid-19 pill could work against Omicron; An analyst cut its rating of Adagio Therapeutics shares. Wall Street stocks are in a holding pattern ahead of a policy decision from the Federal Reserve. Here's what we're watching in Wednesday's trading:

title: Elon Musk Hits Back Against Elizabeth Warren in Twitter Spat Over Tax Policy
summary: Billionaire calls her 'Senator Karen' after she says the Tesla CEO should stop 'freeloading'. Tesla Inc . Chief Executive Elon Musk and Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.) clashed with one another on Twitter after the senator called on the billionaire chief executive to pay more taxes.

title: Three Miles and $400 Apart: Hospital Prices Vary Wildly Even in the Same City
summary: The cost of an ER visit in Boston reveals the wide range of prices at U.S. hospitals. To get inside healthcare costs, The Wall Street Journal looked at newly public data from one market: Boston, home to some of the world's most prominent hospitals.

title: Ryan Seacrest Is Ready to Relax. A Little. The Smallest Possible Amount.
summary: Resume Subscription. The Ryan Seacrest interview is scheduled for 2:30 p.m., but texts from his team about my arrival time begin lighting up the phone well before 1 p.m.: "What is your ETA? He is arriving a bit earlier." And indeed, at 2:27 p.m. a Range Rover rolls to the curb and out of the back bounds Seacrest, his relieved interviewer having only just sprinted into the private back room of Cosme, a farm-to-table Mexican restaurant in Manhattan's Flatiron District, one of Seacrest's favorites since he relocated from Los Angeles four years ago.

title: German Police Raid Antivaccine Extremists Suspected of Plot to Kill Politician
summary: Officials are growing increasingly concerned about the radicalization of Covid-19 skeptics as the country considers a general vaccine mandate. BERLIN-German special police forces carried out raids in the country's South-East targeting a network suspected of conspiring to murder local politicians for their role in implementing Covid-19 restrictions, police said on Wednesday.

title: Can the Stock Market's Big Gains Continue in the Year Ahead? Unlikely.
summary: Investors need to have a more-sober, realistic expectation for future market returns. Despite the continuing pandemic and global jitters about everything from climate change to inflation, the good times have kept rolling in the markets during 2021. The U.S. stock market continued to soar across the board-large-cap, small-cap, growth, value-seemingly every segment of the stock market just kept going up.

title: How to Make a Pink Bathroom Chic
summary: An interior designer shares how she created a very feminine and exuberant bathroom that avoids being too saccharine. WHAT KEEPS THIS obviously youthful and feminine vanity area from making your teeth hurt? Maria Crosby Pollard, the interior designer behind it, had to balance the teenage occupant's love of the very Floridian patterns of the late fashion designer Lilly Pulitzer with the room's decidedly nontropical location of Alexandria, Va. Also on the program: décor that would suit the teen as she ages into adulthood.

title: India Seeks Its Own Solar Industry to Counter China
summary: Resume Subscription. Until recently, one of India's largest renewable energy developers was focused on building massive solar farms using cheap panels imported from China.

title: China's Economy Needs More Help
summary: November figures show consumers struggling; more fiscal and monetary support will be needed to avert an even steeper downturn next year. Chinese policy makers are suddenly sending much stronger signals about supporting growth. The last big data release of 2021, published Wednesday, shows why.

title: China-U.S. Tension Mars Biotech Giant BeiGene's Shanghai Debut
summary: Goldman-sponsored deal is the largest healthcare IPO of 2021. Chinese biotechnology firm BeiGene Ltd. tumbled 16% in its mainland trading debut, after raising $3.5 billion and becoming the first company to be triple-listed in New York, Hong Kong and on Shanghai's STAR Market.

title: The DMV Is No Longer a Bureaucratic Purgatory, DMV Says
summary: Sick of being comedic fodder, agency officials say upgraded technology has put many services online and wait times have been cut drastically. An article last month in The Atlantic declared that root canals were no longer terrible. "The comedians of the 2020s," it said, "will have to find a different way to tell you how comparatively agonizing it is to go to the DMV."

title: China's Covid-19 Lockdowns Starting to Sting
summary: Factories in manufacturing centers in Yangtze River Delta halted production as local governments impose lockdowns. China's lockdown of many factories in the Yangtze River Delta last week in a prolonged battle with Covid-19 has underlined the economic costs of China's stringent pandemic-control measures.

title: How Is Omicron Affecting Air Travel?
summary: Tourism is showing little impact from the new Covid-19 variant, but there are signs it is further delaying business-travel recovery. So far, the impact of the Omicron variant on the airline industry has been more bark than bite. Unfortunately, a loud bark may be enough to keep the lucrative business traveler at bay.

title: I've Tried to Make Travel Better for 20 Years. Mostly It's Gotten Worse.
summary: As Scott McCartney wraps up his time in the Middle Seat, he looks at the many ways that travel has worsened-and the few things that have gotten better. I fear I've failed.

title: In a Bad Year for Biotech Stocks, Deals and Vaccines Were Winners
summary: Analysts expect cash-rich pharma companies to keep buying and vaccine demand to stay high. Biotech stocks have crumbled this year and a number of prominent hedge funds have suffered deep losses.

title: Afghan Women Face Old Family Pressures
summary: Resume Subscription. KABUL-When Marjan Amiri marched for women's rights on the streets of Kabul in September, Taliban gunmen called her a prostitute, kicked her and threatened to shoot her in the head. But what scared the 24-year-old Afghan civil servant most was her father's reaction when she returned home.

title: More People Quit to Take a New Job From an Old Boss
summary: Most Popular News. Workers who want better pay and more flexible schedules are finding new jobs in a surprising but familiar place: their old organizations.

title: Fed Prepares Faster End to Stimulus, Making Earlier Rate Increases Possible
summary: The central bank has signaled a policy pivot that focuses more attention on inflation risks than on employment shortfalls. Federal Reserve officials are likely to quicken the wind-down of their bond-buying stimulus program at the conclusion of their two-day policy meeting on Wednesday, opening the door to interest-rate increases in the first half of next year.

title: Pandemic Accelerated Migration Out of California
summary: Decrease in people moving to the Golden State was particularly severe in the San Francisco Bay Area, where new arrivals fell 45%, study finds. California is losing more than twice as many people to domestic migration as it was before the pandemic, a new report from University of California researchers shows.

title: Rapper Logic's Song About Suicide Prevention Saved Lives, Study Says
summary: The song '1-800-273-8255'-the national suicide prevention hotline-and Logic's ensuing performances led to higher call volume and decrease in suicides, research shows. A song by the musician Logic named for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline phone number might have saved hundreds of lives, according to a new study.

title: Kim Jong Un's Family Tree: What You Need to Know About North Korea's Dynasty
summary: The North Korean regime has lasted longer than the Soviet Union despite economic hardship, human-rights abuses and sometimes deadly family rivalries. The Kim family has governed North Korea since Soviet leader Joseph Stalin installed clan patriarch Kim Il Sung as head of state after World War II. To consolidate and maintain power through three generations, the ruling Kims have purged, coaxed or murdered rivals and elites, sometimes even within the family. To deter American-led military action and secure the regime's longer-term political survival, they have driven the development of nuclear weapons. The family has led the isolated country for more than seven decades-longer than the Soviet Union existed-and remains unchallenged despite widespread poverty, an appalling human-rights record and the pressure of economic sanctions.

title: Kim Yong Ju, Brother of North Korea's Founder, Dies Aged 101
summary: He was the oldest surviving member of the ruling family and once considered a potential candidate to lead the country. SEOUL-Kim Yong Ju, who was the oldest surviving member of North Korea's ruling family and once considered a potential candidate to lead the country, has died. He was 101 years old.

title: U.K. Inflation Accelerates at Fastest Pace in a Decade
summary: Supply-chain problems and higher energy costs turbo charged price rises. LONDON-Inflation in the U.K. accelerated in November to its fastest annual rate in more than a decade, propelled by supply-chain disruptions and higher energy costs that are pushing up consumer prices across many advanced economies.

title: China's Economic Activity Slows on Property Slump, Weak Consumption
summary: Monthly consumption, property and investment indicators weakened, increasing pressure on Beijing to take steps to support growth. HONG KONG-China's economic activity decelerated in November amid a prolonged property slump and sluggish consumption recovery, adding urgency for Beijing to step up efforts to support the world's second-largest economy.

title: House Approves Increase in Debt Ceiling
summary: Planned $2.5 trillion increase in borrowing limit should push next standoff past the midterms. WASHINGTON-Congress passed a measure raising the government's borrowing limit by $2.5 trillion, sending to President Biden's desk legislation that is expected to push the next debt-ceiling standoff past the midterm elections.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
